text.tspan: Kdenlive Model: Timeline moving + snapping helper
When moving items in the timeline, we need “collision detection” and snapping.
In the following example, the lighter clip is dragged over another clip. It cannot be dropped there.
When dragging it to the left, the user would expect it to stick on the right of the other clip until
it is dragged far enough that it can be inserted again.
If a clip cannot be moved to the current mouse position, the helper calculates two points:
The shortest distance to the left and to the right where insertion is possible again. For all
of those points, we know that the right edge of the selected (i.e. dragged) clip must be adjacent
to a left edge of an unselected clip—otherwise we could move it a few frames to the right.
The following algorithm can be used to find the next matching point:
1. Create a list of possible positions (how many frames Δf to move) for the selected clip
2. Sort the list ascendingly, so the smallest Δf is taken first
3. Test all positions in order, and return the first one where no overlaps occur.
If multiple clips are selected and moved together, step 1 needs to be repeated for all clips
in the selection. Example:
This would lead to the following tests (the vertical offset is just for clarity;
clips are all on the same track):
Tests 1, 2, and 4 match here. The algorithm would stop after test 1.
This algorithm can be extended to multiple tracks as it has been extended to multiple clips
per selection.
Another application of this algorithm is snapping to adjacent clips. The difference
is minor: Instead of trying to find the first place to the left (when dragging the clip
this way) where we can put the selected clip, we search for the first place where
another clip stops the selected one.
In this case, the helper takes the left edge of the selected clip and compares it to the
right edge of the clip to the left of it. This way the helper can give feedback about
where snapping is possible.
Performance of the algorithm can be improved by e.g. considering the visible part
of the timeline only, or by limiting the number of “lookahead steps” in a different way.
Author: Simon A. Eugster
